title: d5000
author: d5000
content: Every time we presence a hack, theft or a ransomware wave, attacks on Bitcoin's fungibility increase. Chain analysis by exchanges and other services has already been rampant for several years, but the policies still seem to get tighter and tighter, and we have reached the point where coins are already suspicious because they come from certain exchanges or service providers (not even mixers).The question is: can the Bitcoin community do something to prevent Bitcoin's fungibility being undermined?Some ideas may be:- Read the terms of service of exchanges and service providers, and if they have unacceptable terms regarding the acceptance of "tainted" coins, then avoid them. (On https://kycnot.me, there are summaries of many non-KYC exchanges/services' ToS.) For me it's still acceptable if they reject some coins but then return them to the origin address.- Use CoinJoins and "manual privacy" measures (e.g. randomly transferring coins from addresses to another)- Avoid exchanges who have delisted privacy coins as an act of self-censorship.- Avoid offers of explicitly non-tainted coins on P2P exchanges ("virgin coins" and similar), to avoid the market for these "special" Bitcoins to become too strong, which further undermines Bitcoin's fungibility.- Search and propose alternative ways to deal with crypto heists not putting fungibility in danger, for example simply returning high-risk coins (see above) and ad hoc logging of suspicious deposits/mixing activities/exchanges.Any more ideas?I think this is a crucial topic, because the attacks on fungibility are in reality an attack of one of Bitcoin's central qualities, censorship resistance. This means that a part of Bitcoin's intrinsic value is in danger if fungibility becomes progressively undermined.

Perhaps you can find some ideas from them.

comments.author: d5000
comments.body: Quote from: Catenaccio on March 06, 2025, 03:26:49 AMMany resources are in Bitcoin privacy information and Bitcoin privacy guide. Perhaps you can find some ideas from them.Thanks, these are excellent guides and link lists!I just want to clarify that the ideas I have in mind are of basically three groups:1) Keep your own coins fungible and private - that's where these privacy guides are an excellent resource. The nice side effect is that users following these principles potentially also help other users' coins -- for example: the more CoinJoins exist, the larger the amount of fungible Bitcoins.2) Try to incentive centralized service providers to accept and preserve Bitcoin's fungibility. Of couse some regulations apply, but in most (or all?) areas regulated exchanges are relatively free to decide how they deal with high-risk coins as long as they don't simply ignore them. So the option to return them to the origin is probably always legal.The idea is of course that well-behaving service providers get a competitive edge while fungibility-endangering entities are "boycotted". This may be achieved through education of other users, but also through self-examining your own "consumption" of these services. Unfortunately it's an area not many guides cover, so it's one of the points I like to emphasize a bit 3) and my last point above, to explore possibilities to deal with criminal activity without harming fungibility. This may be the hardest point, but as already written there are examples for best practices.

comments.body: Bitcoin is not fungible. Even Andreas called it and he has probably more knowledge on bitcoin than many people in this forum. The faster we accept this truth, the more realistic solutions we will come up with. The moment we name coins “tainted” and “clean”, we accepted it anyway. Some people insist on saying that all bitcoins are same but they live in their own dream world as the reality is very different. Some people tried to use mixers to make bitcoin fungible but guess what, it didn’t work either because the exchanges could see that your coins were coming from a mixer address and they know what kind of people mainly use mixers…Monero is truly fungible if you want that but the sad part is, the gov killed it already, it has zero adoption. If bitcoin becomes fungible one day, they will do the same thing to bitcoin.

comments.author: BitJannik
comments.body: I really think Bitcoin's fungibility is what keeps it valuable and free from control and I feel like we've got to step up to protect it. Try to stick with non KYC exchanges whenever I can and back platforms that actually care about privacy. Using stuff like conjoin and keeping my coins in my own wallet makes it tougher for those chain analysis folks to tag some bitcoin as 'dirty'. I steer clear of services that ditch privacy coins or push this 'virgin' bitcoin nonsense, it is just creating a messed up two tier vibe that could ruin what makes bitcoin work. Honestly I'd rather see exchanges send flagged coins back to the sender instead of snagging them, it's only fair.

comments.author: Darker45
comments.body: Perhaps we need to return to the basics. We stick to non-custodial wallets to maintain control. We stick to peer-to-peer transactions to avoid third parties. We avoid platforms that can decide on our funds. This is, after all, the primary reason why there's Bitcoin. As a community, there's not much we can do as to the rules and regulations and policies. We can spread awareness, convince others that Bitcoin is fungible, perhaps lobby and coordinate with lawmakers. But, at the end of the day, policymaking is beyond our control. And, whether we like it or not, there are indeed funds that are proceeds from crimes. Wherever they end up, they should be flagged and seized, albeit returned to circulation later on. Even those who strongly advocate for Bitcoin's fungibility must take it upon themselves to help victims of hacks and robberies and theft recover their money should the opportunity arise.

comments.body: part of learning about fungibility EG criminality/illegal links of any currency unit/note.. is that fungibility of someones deposit is not a yes/no 2 optionpeople need to realise the analysis is a % risk tolerance. they actually rate deposits based on a risk percentage and they have thresholds whereby when certain risk tolerances break a threshold, a different level of investigation is triggered by the servicepeople need to realise what actually raises the risk%many dont realise that by actually using privacy tricks and tools actually adds more risk to those coins. which leads to more investigation and possibly the user being frozen from trading and being asked give more KYC and explanation of coin origins and purpose to regain access to trade or to remove their coin and be banned from the service, or worse having the investigation forwarded to authorities which could lead to court action..for instance imagine you are a clean user personally, but you used a privacy tool to swap your coin in a mixer. and the coin you get out was directly last used in some dodgy illicit service. (illicit porn or identity theft trading site, etc) suddenly your coins are classed as high risk to a high 9X% and you are investigated to a high level including having to give more KYC if you want to regain enough access to the service, whilst secretly they are informing on you to the authoritieswhere as if you just deposited your normal coin(unmixed) to the exchange. you wont be investigated and so you are just part of the minutiae of millions of other deposits they receive and dont have time to look twice at...what i find soo obvious is that illicit people want innocent people to fear things, simply to advertise that innocent people should(fake need) go though extra processes.. but this is purely so that the illicit people can get their hands on innocent peoples coins, lowering the illicit persons deposit risk.. whilst leaving the innocent person holding the coins linked to illicit services and left with the headache

comments.author: buwaytress
comments.body: Doesn't blind usage with everything work better than avoiding certain uses? Sure, you can boycott some services that mark or consider linked entities as tainted (I've experienced this already in Europe, they flag coins that come from certain places) but isn't that just another form of complexity to the user?Let people learn to use their own wallets as the barrier (or double, multiple barriers) betwixt the taint and the service, and you solve this anyway without adding the burden of watchfulness on the mainstream user, or inadvertently setting up your own censorship filters. We want mainstream use, then it's just the basics of always controlling your own coins, at least, whenever sending them onward.P.S. Might be an unpopular side to take but I think the regulations should be allowed to run, for regulators to see the folly of their ways. Organic understanding that censorship is pointless for people, or forces them to stay a step ahead, with same end result of resources consumed to cause inconvenience.

comments.author: Ucy
comments.body: Well, I think the Bitcoin community should have worked together and make sure that the Bitcoin features which are meant to protect genuine and honest users from abuses or attacks are not aiding abusers/attackers.Bitcoiners should have done something about the abuse and misuse than wait for people who could add more to the issue to help solve it. The is bound to happen though as humans don't usually ignore their problems otherwise they could grow too big to handle. So, the right approach would be to stop or prevent the spread of crime coins without violating the censorship resistant features of Bitcoin.

comments.author: pooya87
comments.body: The ultimate solution is to stop using anything centralized with [decentralized] bitcoin, that includes replacing CEX with DEX. But that is not happening for some reasons. So here is another approach...We have to see what's happening as war and in war we need to hit back! If we are stuck with centralized exchanges, it is impossible to avoid those that blacklist certain coins with the fake concept of "taint" as suggested in OP because sooner or later they all do the same thing. And that's an attack on Bitcoin's basic principles. So we need to hit them back where it hurts.Imagine if for example next time a CEX like Coinbase or Binance blocked someone's deposit calling it "tainted" a large number of their users withdrew their funds from these exchanges. If people did that, first thing that these exchanges would face is a crisis of running out of coins to cover all these withdrawals which would raise the concerns about their insolvency and increase the number of withdrawals which would increase the pressure on these services.Considering that at the end of the day, these are all businesses that are looking to maximize their profitability, so if they lose a considerable amount of revenue they will be forced to change policies. Next thing you know they willingly remove that taint nonsense from their ToS on their own.The problem is that people are not coordinated and they always think that the problem has happened to someone else and it won't happen to them so they don't care until it also happens to them. Then they become an individual who complains a bit on the internet and is soon forgotten...
